scenarioObject.Prompt: Patient is a 20 year old male was admitted from an outside hospital with complaints of a headache and slurred speech.
scenarioObject.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura

Present Illness History.Output: This previously healthy patient was transferred from an outlying hospital after presenting with a one day history of occipital headaches and slurred speech. The headache began the day prior to admission and the patient felt well enough to visit his girlfriend that night. His girlfriend noted the onset of slurred speech and weakness in the patient's right arm. She took him to the local emergency room. The patient complained of fever, feelings of faintness and occasional chills.

Past Medical History.Output: No prior illnesses or hospitalisations.

Medication.Output: None

Social History.Output: The patient smokes occasional marijuana.

Auscultate Lungs.Output: Lungs were clear to auscultation and percussion.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: There was a IIIVI systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border.

Assess Eyes.Output: The pupils were equally round, reactive to light and accommodation.

Abdomen Examination.Output: The abdomen was soft, nondistended, nontender.

Rectal Examination.Output: Rectal examination was normal

NeckThroat Examination.Output: The neck was normal; there was no thyromegaly or adenopathy. Oropharynx appeared normal.

Assess Head.Output: Normal with no evidence of trauma. Cranial nerves were intact.

Neurologic Exam Record.Output: Neurologic examination revealed that he was alert and oriented to person, place, and time.  Peripheral pulses were normal.

Assess Extremities.Output: The extremities showed no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema; The distal pulses were 2 and equal bilaterally.

Urine Dipstick.Output: 3 to 8 WBCs, 3 to 10 RBCs, and 3 to 10 squamous epithelial cells per HPF. 1 protein, and increased urobilinogen present.

ECG.Output: Normal

Venous Blood Gas.Output: pH: 7.35 (Normal: 7.33 to 7.44), PCO2: 5.2 (Normal: 5 to 6.4kPa), PO2: 5.9 (Normal: > 5.3 kPa), HCO3: 24 (Normal: 22 to 28 mmolL), Base Excess: 1 (Normal: 2), Saturation: 75 (Normal: 72 to 75%), Lactate: 0.7 (Normal: 0.5 to 2.2 mmolL)

UREA and Electrolytes.Output: Sodium: 141 (Normal: 135 to 145 mmolL), Potassium: 4.2 (Normal: 3.5 to 5.0 mmolL), Urea: 5.6 (Normal: 2.5 to 6.7 mmolL), Creatinine: 135 (Normal: 70 to 150 micromolL), eGFR: 70 (Normal: >90mlmin1.73m2)

Clotting Test.Output: Prothrombin Time: 12 (Normal: 10 to 14 seconds), APTT: 28 (Normal: 22 to 36 seconds), Fibrinogen: 4.1 (Normal: 1.5 to 4.5 gL)

FBC.Output: Hb: 74 (Normal: 130 to 180 gL), Hct: 0.22 (Normal: 0.40 to 0.54 LL), MCV: 100 (Normal: 80 to 100 fl), WBC: 8.4 (Normal: 3.6 to 11.0 x 109L), Neut: 7.2 (Normal: 1.8 to 7.5  x 109L), Lymph's: 3.1 (Normal: 1.0 to 4.0  x 109L), Platelet Count: 25 (Normal: 140 to 400 x 109L)

scenarioObject.Prompt: Patient is a 60 year old male presented with 2 day history of bloody diarrhoea.
scenarioObject.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Ulcerative Colitis.

Present Illness History.Output: The patient has a history of hypertension, osteoarthritis and diverticulitis. He had been doing well until about three weeks prior to admission, when he developed loose, watery bowel movements and an associated crampy left lower quadrant abdominal pain. The bowel movements occurred about 45 times per day. Prior to admission, he noted blood in his bowel movements, as well as fevers to 39 degrees celsius, chills and sweats. He did note fatigue and a decrease in weight of 14 pounds relative to his baseline.

Past Medical History.Output: Significant for diverticulitis: diagnosed first in 1999 after a presentation with fresh blood in stool, relatively asymptomatic recently, hypertension, osteoarthritis in his hands, and recurrent epistaxis.

Medication.Output: Diltiazem and hydrochlorothiazide, neither started recently.

Social History.Output: Unremarkable.

Auscultate Lungs.Output: Lungs were clear to auscultation.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: His cardiac rhythm was regular and no extra heart sounds or murmurs were appreciated.

Assess Eyes.Output: Conjunctivae were pale. The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation.

Abdomen Examination.Output: His abdominal examination revealed bowel sounds and mild tenderness to palpation over the left lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. No masses or organomegaly were present.

Rectal Examination.Output: Rectal examination revealed no palpable masses or obvious haemorrhoids. The stool was grossly bloody.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: The neck and oropharynx were normal.

Assess Head.Output: Normal

Neurologic Exam Record.Output: Neurological examination was normal.

One week prior to admission, the arthralgia again worsened, and he developed fever and headache.

scenarioObject.Prompt: Patient is a 58 year old female presented with shortness of breath.
scenarioObject.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Aortic Dissection.

Present Illness History.Output: The patient had a history of hypertension and had had three weeks of intermittent left sided chest pain. The pain radiated to the back. There was no change with exertion. Pains lasted for approximately one minute. She also complained of increasing shortness of breath over the previous month. She became dyspneic performing minimum household chores. She had an occasional nonproductive cough. She had been seen by a GP prior to admission, found to be hypertensive and started on treatment. She complained of night sweats and fever over the previous week but had no weight loss.

Past Medical History.Output: She had previous trauma to the right eye resulting in blindness. She had a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral oophorectomy in the 1990's.

Medication.Output: Her medications on admission included verapamil 180 mg once per day, ramipril 5 mg once per day, and furosemide 20 mg once per day

Social History.Output: She smoked for ten years, but stopped twenty years ago. She drinks one bottle of beer every six months. She works in the home and lives with her husband.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: The first and second heart sounds were normal. There was an S4 and a IIVI systolic ejection murmur.

Assess Eyes.Output: Her pupils were equally round and reactive to light. The right cornea was opacified.

Abdomen Examination.Output: The abdomen was soft and nontender with no masses, or organomegaly.

Rectal Examination.Output: NAD and faecal occult blood was negative.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: There was no thyromegaly or adenopathy. Jugular venous pulsations were visible at 8 cm.

Assess Head.Output: Normal.

Neurologic Exam Record.Output: Neurologic exam was normal.

scenarioObject.Prompt: Patient is a 62 year old male admitted for fevers and generalised weakness.
scenarioObject.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Miliary TB.

Present Illness History.Output: Ten years prior to admission, the patient developed pancytopenia. Evaluation included a bone marrow biopsy which revealed refractory anaemia. One month prior to admission the patient presented to an outside hospital for diagnostic evaluation. Examination revealed a high temperature, a right inguinal hernia, and a right axillary mass (3 cm in diameter, no fluctuance, slightly tender).

Past Medical History.Output: Myelodysplastic syndrome, Type II Diabetes (10 years, dietcontrolled), hypertension (10 years).

Medication.Output: GCSF (Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor), verapamil, Fybogel

Social History.Output: Regular (daily) smoker, has not travelled recently.

Assess Eyes.Output: The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation.

Abdomen Examination.Output: Abdomen was distended, with shifting dullness, a right inguinal hernia (reducible), and normal bowel sounds.

trials.treatmentPlan:
Full history inc travel history
A to E exam, PR exam
Bloods  FBC, UEs, CRP, LFTs, clotting, GS, 
ECG (to ensure no ischaemia secondary to anaemia)
Blood transfusion 1 unit PRBC given Hb 50, aim Hb >70
If active bleeding, consider CT angio
Cover with antibiotics e.g. CoAmox for diverticulitis
Referral to gen surg for LGIBdiverticulitis
Consdier CT AP for diverticulitisperf

Present Illness History.Output: The patient was well until 4 weeks prior to admission when he developed arthralgia in his wrists and shoulders. He also developed fatigue. He began taking ibuprofen, but developed abdominal pain. OGD (Oesophagogastroduodenoscopy) showed several gastric ulcers. One week prior to admission, the arthralgia again worsened, and he developed fever and headache.

Past Medical History.Output: No prior illnesses or hospitalizations.

Medication.Output: Ranitidine.

Social History.Output: He is divorced, and lives alone. He denied tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use.

trials.treatmentPlan:
Full history inc travel history, systems review, FH
A to E and examination of joints and neuro and temporal artery (ensure no other cause for fever)
Urine dip (renal involvement)
ECG  sinus tachy
Bloods  FBC, UEs, CRP
Dependent on joint exam  if single joint involvement with effusion then consider aspiration for MCScrystal arthropathy
If symmetrical, large joint involvement consider starting on high dose steroids (or if concern re GCA) and discuss with Rheum for urgent OP follow up e.g. ambulatory
If concern re GCA then urgent follow up with OpthalRheum

trials.presentation: Patient is a 58 year old female presented with shortness of breath.
trials.prompt: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Aortic Dissection.

trialInfoSet.Prompt: Patient is a 58 year old female presented with shortness of breath.
trialInfoSet.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Aortic Dissection.

Present Illness History.Output: The patient had a history of hypertension and had had three weeks of intermittent left sided chest pain. The pain radiated to the back. There was no change with exertion. Pains lasted for approximately one minute. She also complained of increasing shortness of breath over the previous month. She became dyspneic performing minimum household chores. She had an occasional nonproductive cough. She had been seen by a GP prior to admission, found to be hypertensive and started on treatment. trials.presentation: Patient is a 62 year old male admitted for fevers and generalised weakness.
trials.prompt: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Miliary TB.

trialInfoSet.Prompt: Patient is a 62 year old male admitted for fevers and generalised weakness.
trialInfoSet.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Miliary TB.

Present Illness History.Output: Ten years prior to admission, the patient developed pancytopenia. Evaluation included a bone marrow biopsy which revealed refractory anaemia. The patient's myelodysplastic syndrome remained indolent throughout the subsequent 10 years. Three months prior to admission the patient developed daily fevers and fatigue. One month prior to admission the patient presented to an outside hospital for diagnostic evaluation. Examination revealed a high temperature, a right inguinal hernia, and a right axillary mass (3 cm in diameter, no fluctuance, slightly tender).

Past Medical History.Output: Myelodysplastic syndrome, Type II Diabetes (10 years, dietcontrolled), hypertension (10 years).

Medication.Output: GCSF (Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor), verapamil, Fybogel

Social History.Output: Regular (daily) smoker, has not travelled recently.

Auscultate Lungs.Output: Lungs exam revealed decreased breath sounds at right base with dullness to percussion. Crackles on the right and left lower zones, and crackles on the right middle zone.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: Cardiovascular system was within normal limits.

Assess Eyes.Output: The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation.

Abdomen Examination.Output: Abdomen was distended, with shifting dullness, a right inguinal hernia (reducible), and normal bowel sounds.

Rectal Examination.Output: Rectal exam was unremarkable.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: Within normal limits

Assess Head.Output: No irregularities.

Neurologic Exam Record.Output: Within normal limits.

Assess Extremities.Output: Mild pedal oedema, multiple ecchymoses of various sizes.

Urine Dipstick.Output: Specific gravity 1.020 (normal: 1.005 to 1.025), 3 to 5 RBC (normal: <3 RBC) 0 to 3 WBC, no casts.

ECG.Output: No irregularities

Venous Blood Gas.Output: pH: 7.47 (Normal: 7.33 to 7.44), PCO2: 6.1 (Normal: 5 to 6.4kPa), PO2: 6.1 (Normal: > 5.3 kPa), HCO3: 27 (Normal: 22 to 28 mmolL), Base Excess: 1 (Normal: 2), Saturation: 72 (Normal: 72 to 75%), Lactate: 1.2 (Normal: 0.5 to 2.2  mmolL)

UREA and Electrolytes.Output: Sodium: 129 (Normal: 135 to 145 mmolL), Potassium: 3.5 (Normal: 3.5 to 5.0 mmolL), Urea: 5.5 (Normal: 2.5 to 6.7 mmolL), Creatinine: 145 (Normal: 70 to 150 micromolL), eGFR: 42.8 (Normal: >90mlmin1.73m2)

Clotting Test.Output: Prothrombin Time: 11 (Normal: 10 to 14 seconds), APTT: 23 (Normal: 22 to 36 seconds), Fibrinogen: 2.2 (Normal: 1.5 to 4.5 gL)

FBC.Output: Hb: 94 (Normal: 130 to 180 gL), Hct: 0.28 (Normal: 0.40 to 0.54 LL), MCV: 87 (Normal: 80 to 100 fl), WBC: 6.3 (Normal: 3.6 to 11.0 x 109L), Neut: 5.5 (Normal: 1.8 to 7.5  x 109L), Lymph's: 0.6 (Normal: 1.0 to 4.0  x 109L), Platelet Count: 85 (Normal: 140 to 400 x 109L)

Other Biochemistry Tests.Output: Chloride: 90 (Normal: 95 to 105 mmoll), Glucose: 8.5 (Normal: 3.5 to 5.5 mmolL), Protein Total: 66 (Normal: 60 to 80 gL), Albumin: 29 (Normal: 36 to 50 gL), AST (SGOT): 49 (Normal: 5 to 35 UL), ALP: 151 (Normal: 30 to 150 UL)

Chest XRay.Output: Right pleural effusion, layers on lateral xray.

debrief.Hypothesis: How synthesis of differential diagnoses are formulated using specific bits of evidence  which evidence and how quickly are clinicians using them?
debrief.DiagnosticApproach:
History, exam, bedside tests e.g. ECG, bloods, imaging, micro, further tests
As ED clinician  most of this focuses on history and exam and immediate ix e.g. ECG, urine dip, bloods, CT head or abdopelvis, CXR
Try to have a list of possible differentials, and each piece of information moves differentials either higher likelihood or lower likelihood to then tailor best investigation e.g. troponin vs CTPA
debrief.Feedback:
Bloods slightly borderline at times e.g. CRP
Would be useful to perhaps have space to enter specific questions you would like to ask in history or any other tests you would like (as this would more closely mimic if you were to see this patient in real life)
Also could be made slightly clearer that we are supposed to use the least number of clues we could (I think)

Blood transfusion 1 unit PRBC given Hb 50, aim Hb >70

Cover with antibiotics e.g. CoAmox for diverticulitis

Full history inc travel history, systems review, FH
A to E and examination of joints and neuro and temporal artery (ensure no other cause for fever)
Urine dip (renal involvement)
ECG  sinus tachy
Bloods  FBC, UEs, CRP
Dependent on joint exam  if single joint involvement with effusion then consider aspiration for MCScrystal arthropathy
If symmetrical, large joint involvement consider starting on high dose steroids (or if concern re GCA) and discuss with Rheum for urgent OP follow up e.g. ambulatory
If concern re GCA then urgent follow up with OpthalRheum
